TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine, smectitic Typic Glossocryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Wetterhorn stony loam - forest.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--3 to 1 inch; undecomposed organic material consisting mainly of needles, bark, twigs, and leaves.
02--1 inch to 0; partially decomposed organic material like that of the horizon above.
A2--0 to 12 inches; pinkish gray (7.5YR 6/2) loam, brown (7.5YR 4/2) moist; weak medium platy structure that parts to moderate fine granules; soft, very friable; vesicular; 25 percent stones; slightly acid (pH 6.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (6 to 13 inches thick)
A&B--12 to 20 inches; mixed colors including pinkish gray (7.5YR 6/2) and brown (7.5YR 5/3) loam, brown (7.5YR 4/3) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, very friable; this horizon consists of clayey material like that of the underlying horizon embedded in a lighter colored matrix like that of the overlying horizons; few thin glossy patches on the more clayey peds; 25 percent stones; slightly acid (pH 6.0); gradual wavy boundary.  (6 to 10 inches thick)
B2t--20 to 36 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/3) heavy clay loam, brown (7.5YR 4/3) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure; hard, friable; thin nearly continuous wax-like coatings on faces of peds; thin wax-like coatings and fillings in root channels; 30 percent stones; slightly acid (pH 6.0); clear smooth boundary.  (8 to 17 inches thick)
R--36 inches; quartz latite bedrock.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Gunnison County, Colorado; in a road cut southwest of Powderhorn, Colorado; on the Indian Creek drainageway in Sec. 35, T. 46 N., R. 3 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Thickness of solum and depth to bedrock range from 20 to 40 inches.  These soils are slightly acid to neutral throughout.  Some pedons have thin dark colored A horizons. Average cation exchange capacity to the base of the argillic horizon ranges from 60 to 100 millequivalents per 100 grams of clay.  Rock fragments range from 15 to 35 percent in a major portion of the solum.  Mean annual soil temperature ranges from 32 to 46 degrees F., mean summer soil temperature from 38 to 46 degrees F. with an 0 horizon at least 4 inches thick and under a good crown cover.
The A2 horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 6 or 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist and chroma of 2 through 4.  It usually has platy structure but has subangular blocky or granular structure in some pedons. This horizon is soft or slightly hard and is neutral to medium acid.
The B2t horizon has hue of 10YR through 5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  It is typically heavy clay loam or light clay in the matrix but clay ranges from 35 to 50 percent, silt from 15 to 45 percent, and sand from 15 to 45 percent.  Oriented clay films occur in some part of this horizon. It is neutral to medium acid.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  These are the Azarman, Bead, Blackleaf, Chubbs, Cowdrey, Dell, Foxton, Gateway, Hatch, Lail, McVickers, Mikesell, Sielo, and Soldier series.  Azarman, Bead, Blackleaf, Dell, Lail, Mikesell and Soldier soils lack a lithic contact at depths shallower than 40 inches.  Bead, Lail, Foxton, McVickers and Soldier soils have lithochromic hue of 5YR or redder.  Chubbs soils are calcareous above 40 inches, and have continuous horizons of secondary carbonate accumulation.  Gateway, Hatch, Mikesell and Sielo soils have a paralithic contact at depths of less than 40 inches.  Also, Gateway soils have less than 15 percent coarse fragments throughout the solum and have argillic horizons that contain less than 15 percent fine or coarser sand.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Wetterhorn soils are on moderately to steeply sloping mountain sides and ridges.  Slopes usually range from 6 to about 50 percent.  These soils formed in medium to moderately fine textured noncalcareous sediments that have weathered from underlying bedrock.  At the type location these soils occur at elevations in excess of 7,500 feet.  Average annual precipitation is about 20 inches with peak periods of precipitation in the spring and early summer.  Mean annual temperature is 34 degrees F., and mean summer temperature is 48 degrees F.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Shule and Vulcan soils.  Shule soils have a fine-loamy control section.  Vulcan soils have more than 35 percent rock fragments.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium to slow runoff; slow permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: These soils are used for forestry, as native pastureland, and for recreational purposes.  Principal native vegetation is Englemann spruce, Douglas-fir, scattered aspen, and an understory of grasses and shrubs.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Mountainous areas of Colorado and Wyoming.  The series is of moderate extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Johnson County (Southern Johnson County Area), Wyoming, 1971.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  OSED scanned by NSSQA and cleaned up by Colorado.  Last revised by state 7/73.
